paragraphs.text: HOW TO ACCOMPLISH THE MAHAMUDRA THAT IS THE RESULTANT UNION OF NO MORE LEARNING, THE STATE POSSESSING THE SEVEN PRE-EMINENT QUALITIES OF EMBRACE
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW TO ACCOMPLISH THE MAHAMUDRA THAT IS THE RESULTANT UNION OF NO MORE LEARNING, THE STATE POSSESSING THE SEVEN PRE-EMINENT QUALITIES OF EMBRACE

paragraphs.text: The explanation of the causal Mahamudra meditations has now been completed, including the instructions on the union that needs learning. The goal of allMahayana training is the attainment of fullenlightenment: theUnion of No More Learning. This resultant Mahamudra is now presented in five parts:
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW TO ACCOMPLISH THE MAHAMUDRA THAT IS THE RESULTANT UNION OF NO MORE LEARNING, THE STATE POSSESSING THE SEVEN PRE-EMINENT QUALITIES OF EMBRACE

paragraphs.text: 1	Theplace where Buddhahood is attained
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW TO ACCOMPLISH THE MAHAMUDRA THAT IS THE RESULTANT UNION OF NO MORE LEARNING, THE STATE POSSESSING THE SEVEN PRE-EMINENT QUALITIES OF EMBRACE

paragraphs.text: 2	The basis upon which Buddhahood is attained
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW TO ACCOMPLISH THE MAHAMUDRA THAT IS THE RESULTANT UNION OF NO MORE LEARNING, THE STATE POSSESSING THE SEVEN PRE-EMINENT QUALITIES OF EMBRACE

paragraphs.text: 3	The way in which Buddhahood is attained
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW TO ACCOMPLISH THE MAHAMUDRA THAT IS THE RESULTANT UNION OF NO MORE LEARNING, THE STATE POSSESSING THE SEVEN PRE-EMINENT QUALITIES OF EMBRACE

paragraphs.text: 4	The good qualities of a Buddha
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW TO ACCOMPLISH THE MAHAMUDRA THAT IS THE RESULTANT UNION OF NO MORE LEARNING, THE STATE POSSESSING THE SEVEN PRE-EMINENT QUALITIES OF EMBRACE

paragraphs.text: 5	An explanation of the relationships of serial and reverse order
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW TO ACCOMPLISH THE MAHAMUDRA THAT IS THE RESULTANT UNION OF NO MORE LEARNING, THE STATE POSSESSING THE SEVEN PRE-EMINENT QUALITIES OF EMBRACE

paragraphs.text: THE PLACE WHERE BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED
paragraphs.parent_section: THE PLACE WHERE BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: According to Secret Mantra, there are three places in which Buddhahood can be attained: (1) thePure Land ofAkanishta, (2) thedesire realm, and (3) a place that is neither Akanishta nor the desire realm. In theMahayanaSutras, however, it is asserted that we can attain perfect Buddhahood only in Akanishta. Considering that it was BuddhaShakyamuni who made both assertions, which one is to be accepted as correct? Is there a contradiction between Sutra andSecret Mantra? There is no contradiction, because Buddha’s assertion that full enlightenment can be attained only in Akanishta was made with specific disciples in mind – those who have weak minds or who lack the ability to practise the highest form of Secret Mantra. To those who are able to practise Highest Yoga Tantra, however, Buddha taught that enlightenment could be attained while still in the desire realm. Thus, there is no discrepancy between these two assertions; it is only because they are meant for beings of different capacities that there appears to be a contradiction.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE PLACE WHERE BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: Buddha’s Secret Mantra teachings convey his ultimate intention in the same way as theMadhyamika-Prasangika system conveys his ultimate view. Buddha taught four different philosophical systems according to the different capacities of his disciples, and each system is presented as a method for realizing emptiness. Although these four systems appear to contradict one another, they actually provide a graded sequence of training whereby we can eventually attain the correct view of emptiness. The only way to prove that the Madhyamika-Prasangika system is ultimately correct is through logical reasoning and personal experience. In a similar fashion, Secret Mantra is proved to be the ultimate method by the fact that those who have the ability to practiseHighest Yoga Tantra can attain perfect Buddhahood within a single life. Indeed, it is only through the practice of Highest Yoga Tantra that we can attain perfect Buddhahood at all.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE PLACE WHERE BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: According to Secret Mantra, Buddhahood is attained in Akanishta by aBodhisattva who has reached the tenth ground through the Sutra paths of thePerfection Vehicle. Such a Bodhisattva will not be able to proceed past the tenth ground without engaging in the practices of Highest Yoga Tantra. Because such a Bodhisattva will not be able to attain Buddhahood without receiving theempowerments of Secret Mantra and entering into the actual paths of Highest Yoga Tantra, at this point he or she will receive these empowerments and then go on to attain enlightenment in Akanishta.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE PLACE WHERE BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: If the practitioner is someone who has followed the two stages of Secret Mantra from the beginning and is going to attain enlightenment in that life, it is definite that he or she will attain Buddhahood within the desire realm. For example, the three Yogis mentioned earlier –Gyalwa Ensapa,Dharmavajra, and Milarepa – all attained Buddhahood in Tibet.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE PLACE WHERE BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: Finally, the third place in which Buddhahood can be attained is neither Akanishta nor the desire realm. Buddhahood is attained here by a Secret Mantra practitioner who attains the isolated mind of ultimate example clear light at the time of death. When the clear light of death ceases, such a practitioner will attain theillusory body instead of taking an ordinaryintermediate state body. It is with this illusory body – in a place that is neither Akanishta nor the desire realm – that such a Bodhisattva attains Buddhahood.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE PLACE WHERE BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: Besides these three types of being, there are no other types of being who can attain Buddhahood and no other places in which enlightenment can be attained.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE PLACE WHERE BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: THE BASIS UPON WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED
paragraphs.parent_section: THE BASIS UPON WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: There are three realms withinsamsara: thedesire realm, theform realm, and theformless realm. Of all the beings in the desire realm, onlyhumans can attainBuddhahood within one life because only they are endowed with the physical prerequisites – the sixelements listed earlier. Among the form realm beings, only tenth-ground Bodhisattvas dwelling in Akanishta can attain enlightenment through the path ofSecret Mantra. Formless realm beings cannot progress towards enlightenment through the paths of either Sutra or Secret Mantra.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE BASIS UPON WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: THE WAY IN WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED
paragraphs.parent_section: THE WAY IN WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: This explanation is given in three parts, corresponding to the three types of being described above:
paragraphs.parent_section: THE WAY IN WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: (1)	HowBuddhahood is attained in Akanishta
paragraphs.parent_section: THE WAY IN WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: (2)	How Buddhahood is attained in the desire realm
paragraphs.parent_section: THE WAY IN WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: (3)	How Buddhahood is attained in a place that is neither
paragraphs.parent_section: THE WAY IN WHICH BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED

paragraphs.text: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN AKANISHTA
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN AKANISHTA

paragraphs.text: It was stated earlier that to practiseHighest Yoga Tantra, a person must have the sixelements found within the human body. The tenth-ground Bodhisattva in Akanishta, however, is an exception to this in that, although his body is that of a form realm god, it nevertheless contains the red and whitedrops, and so he can experience thespontaneous great bliss that arises in dependence upon these elements. Thus, he or she is not an ordinary god of theform realm.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN AKANISHTA

paragraphs.text: When such aBodhisattva is abiding on the tenth ground, the Buddhas of the ten directions gather around him and encourage him to enter the path of Secret Mantra. They point out that his present meditative concentration is not powerful enough to abandon theobstructions to omniscience and bring him to enlightenment; onlymeaning clear light has this power. They then confer upon him thewisdom-mudraempowerment and present him with anaction mudra. The Bodhisattva then enters into meditation with his or her consort and develops the eight signs – from the mirage-like appearance to the all-emptyclear light – in conjunction with emptiness. When his all-empty clear light of spontaneous great bliss realizes emptiness directly, the Bodhisattva attains meaning clear light. Thus, he is an exception in that he does not need to practisegeneration stage, or any meditation up to and including theimpure illusory body of completion stage, to attain meaning clear light.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN AKANISHTA

paragraphs.text: With the attainment of meaning clear light, the Bodhisattva enters the Secret Mantrapath of seeing and becomes a Secret Mantra Superior on the fourth stage of completion stage. Following this, at the first moment of the mind of black near-attainment of reverse order, he or she attains the pure illusory body and enters the Secret Mantra path of meditation. Then, the next time he enters themeditative equipoise of meaning clear light, he will attain the fifth stage of completion stage – theunion that needs learning. Finally, he will enter into the meditative equipoise in which the very lastobstructions to omniscience are removed. At that point, he attains the Path of No More Learning, or full enlightenment, the resultant Mahamudra union that is the state possessing theseven pre-eminent qualities of embrace.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN AKANISHTA

paragraphs.text: This way of attaining Buddhahood is peculiar to the tenth-ground Bodhisattva of thePerfection Vehicle. He or she is able to attain enlightenment in this way through the force of the vastcollections ofmerit andwisdom already accumulated during countless aeons on the Sutra path.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN AKANISHTA

paragraphs.text: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: Most practitioners of the path of Secret Mantra will attain Buddhahood in the body of a desire realm human. As explained before, a Yogi who has reached the fifth stage – the union that needs learning – has nearly completed the entire path. He has no new objects of knowledge to realize; he simply has to improve the quality of his existing realizations. In this way, he or she will remove the remaining obstacles to enlightenment – the obstructions to omniscience – and attain Buddhahood.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: The obstructions to omniscience prevent the mind from realizing all objects of knowledge directly and simultaneously. Even though a Yogi of the fifth stage is very advanced, he or she still has not abandoned these obstructions. When this Yogi is in meditative equipoise on emptiness, he or she cannot at the same time perform actions such as giving teachings. In other words, the Yogi cannot be absorbed in meditative equipoise and engage in the activities ofsubsequent attainment simultaneously. A fully realized Buddha, on the other hand, has the ability to perform beneficial deeds without ever rising from deep meditation on the ultimate nature of reality – this is one of the excellent qualities of an enlightened being. To attain such an exalted state, the Yogi must repeatedly enter the meditative equipoise of meaning clear light so as to remove all the remaining obstructions to omniscience. That is why the union of the fifth stage is known as the ‘union that needs learning’.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: The principal meditations for such a practitioner are the external method ofaction mudra yoga and the twointernal concentrations previously described. The purpose of these practices is to eradicate all obstructions by means of meaning clear light. The method of embracing the action mudra can be explained by taking the example of a man whosepersonal Deity isHeruka. He visualizes himself as Heruka embracing his consortVajravarahi and, through the force of this embrace, all his windsenter, abide, and dissolve within the indestructible drop at his heart. With this dissolution, the eight signs appear and are experienced in conjunction with emptiness. When the all-empty clear light arises, his mind mixes indistinguishably with emptiness, like water mixing with water. At this stage, the experienced Yogi can remain in the state of all-empty clear light for as long as he wishes. This practice must be performed again and again until perfect Buddhahood is attained.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: When the Yogi rises from the meditative equipoise of clear light, he will experience the minds of black near-attainment, red increase, white appearance, and so forth. With each successive sign, his mind will become more and more gross in nature until, eventually, he once again engages in daily activities, such as expounding Dharma. During this period of subsequent attainment, he will no longer have the mind of clear light because it will already have ceased when the mind of black near-attainment arose. Whenever he wishes to manifest this very subtle mind of clear light again, he must either enter into meditation with the action mudra or perform the internal concentrations.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: The clear light experienced by someone on the level of union is meaning clear light. By using this mind to meditate single-pointedly on emptiness, all nine levels of the obstructions to omniscience will gradually be eliminated and eventually the Yogi will attain enlightenment. As with meaning clear light, this enlightenment will be attained at dawn, the symbol of the all-empty clear light.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: Let us suppose that our personal Deity isHeruka and that, after accomplishing all the stages so far described, we have today received signs indicating that we are ready to attain Buddhahood. We now go to ourSpiritual Guide and make elaborate outer, inner, and secret offerings. At midnight, our Spiritual Guide will appear to us in the form of Heruka, as will all the Buddhas of the ten directions. He will then grant us thewisdom-mudraempowerment and present us with anaction mudra in the form ofVajravarahi. Through the force of embracing her, we will experience the eight signs and, when the all-emptyclear light arises, our mind will mix indistinguishably with emptiness. We will then remain in this state of meditative equipoise until dawn.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: During this time, our mind of meaning clear light will become the direct antidote to the remaining obstructions. This consciousness, which is our last mind as a sentient being, is known as the ‘vajra-likeconcentration of thepath of meditation’. When the vajra-like concentration overcomes the very last obstructions to omniscience at dawn, we will become a fully enlightened being. At that time, our mind of clear light realizing emptiness will become indestructible and constant; never again will we experience the minds of black near-attainment, red increase, or any of the other grosser states of consciousness. From that time onwards, we will experience without break the all-empty clear light realizing emptiness.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: With the total abandonment at dawn of the obstructions to omniscience, our mind of meaning clear light will become the resultantTruth Body of a Buddha and our pure illusory body the resultantForm Body. We will have attained the Union of No More Learning, the state possessing the seven pre-eminent qualities of embrace. For us, there will no longer be any difference betweenmeditative equipoise andsubsequent attainment; all objects of knowledge will be realized simultaneously within a single mind in a single moment because even the most subtledualistic appearance will have been eliminated. Our clear light mind will simultaneously perceive all objects of knowledge as clearly as ordinary beings see their reflection in a mirror.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN THEDESIRE REALM

paragraphs.text: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN A PLACE THAT IS NEITHER
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN A PLACE THAT IS NEITHER

paragraphs.text: In the discussion of the four joys, it was stated that there comes a time when the Secret Mantra meditator who is ready to experience theisolated mind of ultimate example clear light must either accept anaction mudra and perform those practices that will cause thepervading wind to dissolve into the indestructible drop at the heart, or decide not to accept such a mudra but wait until the clear light of death, when all the winds will naturally dissolve there. What happens in the former case has already been described; the latter case can now be explained as follows.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN A PLACE THAT IS NEITHER

paragraphs.text: When such a Yogi experiences theclear light of death, he or she will attain theisolated mind of ultimate example clear light. Then, instead of entering the intermediate state, when this clear light mind ceases such a Yogi will arise in the form of theillusory body in a place that is neither Akanishta nor the desire realm. If the meditator’spersonal Deity is Heruka, Buddhahood will be attained in Heruka’sPure Land, if it isGuhyasamaja, then it will be in Guhyasamaja’s Pure Land, and so forth.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN A PLACE THAT IS NEITHER

paragraphs.text: The illusory body initially attained by this Yogi is the impureillusory body because it arises through the force of the isolated mind of ultimate example clear light. With this impure illusory body, the Yogi repeatedly engages in the external method and the two internal concentrations previously described. Through these methods, the Yogi eventually attainsmeaning clear light, at which point he or she enters the Secret Mantrapath of seeing and becomes a Secret MantraSuperior. Arising from this meaning clear light, he or she attains the pure illusory body and, soon afterwards, the union that needs learning. From this point until the attainment ofenlightenment, the path is the same as that outlined above.
paragraphs.parent_section: HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS ATTAINED IN A PLACE THAT IS NEITHER

paragraphs.text: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: A Yogi who attains enlightenment does so in the form of the CompleteEnjoyment Body. This holy body, which is also known as the ‘primordialBuddha’, possesses theseven pre-eminent qualities of embrace:
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: (1) The Complete Enjoyment Body is adorned by the thirty-twomajor signs and the eighty minor indications. These signs and indications are the distinctive characteristics of a Buddha’s form, indicating the many ways in which an enlightened being is superior to sentient beings. Such characteristics include the crown protuberance (ushnisha), wisdom hair curl, elongated ears, and other signs that signify the unsurpassable qualities of a fully enlightened Buddha. They indicate not only that a Buddha is free from all the fears and sufferings of samsara, and has completely abandoned theobstructions to liberation and omniscience, but also that his or her body is not subject to degeneration, sickness, ageing, or death.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: (2) The Complete Enjoyment Body embraces awisdom mudra. This feature of theFather and Mother facing one another symbolizes that enlightenment is attained through completing the practices of embracing and thereby experiencingspontaneous great bliss that meditates on emptiness.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: (3) An enlightened being’s mind always remains in a state of spontaneous great bliss. This is a further mark of the superiority of a Buddha’s mind over the minds of sentient beings.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: (4) A Buddha’s spontaneous great bliss is always mixed with emptiness. Without moving from this state of total absorption, an enlightened being sees all objects of knowledge as clearly as a glass bead held in the palm of the hand. This demonstrates the exalted quality of a Buddha’s wisdom.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: (5) A Buddha’s mind of greatcompassion for all sentient beings never wavers. This feature demonstrates that an enlightened being’s mind is unstained by even the slightestself-cherishing thought, and that such a being benefits all other beings without exception.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: (6) The continuum of an enlightened being’s body never ceases. This indicates that the indestructiblevajra body has been attained.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: (7) A Buddha’s emanations pervade the entire universe, and his or her activities for the benefit of others never cease.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: This has been just a short description of the primordialBuddha: the Enjoyment BodyVajradhara. If all the excellent qualities of such a being were listed in detail, the description would run to many pages. Further explanation of the excellent qualities of a Buddha’s body, speech, and mind are given in the eighth chapter ofMaitreya’sOrnament of Clear Realizationsand its many commentaries, and byChandrakirti inGuide to the Middle Way. A commentary to the latter can be found in the bookOcean of Nectar.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE GOOD QUALITIES OF A BUDDHA

paragraphs.text: AN EXPLANATION OF THERELATIONSHIPS OF SERIAL AND REVERSE ORDER
paragraphs.parent_section: AN EXPLANATION OF THERELATIONSHIPS OF SERIAL AND REVERSE ORDER

paragraphs.text: By relying upon ourSpiritual Guide, we have a special opportunity to progress through the stages of Mahayana practice and attain the realizations ofrenunciation,bodhichitta, and the correct view of emptiness. With this firm foundation, we are suitably qualified to enter into the practices ofgeneration stage meditation of Secret Mantra. In dependence upon the experience of generation stage, we have the opportunity to practiseisolated body andisolated speech of completion stage. Through the force of accomplishing these two, we can successfully complete the practice ofisolated mind, and success in this enables us to attain the illusory body andmeaning clear light. Through the force of meaning clear light, we can attain the Mahamudra that is theunion of the two truths. On the basis of this Mahamudra, we eventually attain Buddhahood: the resultant Mahamudra Union possessing the seven pre-eminent qualities of embrace. This step-by-step progression – from our initial reliance upon our Spiritual Guide up to our attainment of full enlightenment – is the serial order relationship of thestages of the path.
paragraphs.parent_section: AN EXPLANATION OF THERELATIONSHIPS OF SERIAL AND REVERSE ORDER

paragraphs.text: As for the reverse order relationship, this is as follows. The attainment of Mahamudra Union possessingseven pre-eminent qualities of embrace depends upon our prior attainment of the Mahamudra that is the union of the two truths. This in turn depends upon our attaining meaning clear light, which depends upon the prior attainment of theillusory body. The illusory body is attained in dependence upon attaining isolated mind, and this in turn depends upon attaining isolated speech and isolated body of completion stage. The attainment of isolated body of completion stage depends upon accomplishing generation stage meditations, and this depends upon our realizations of thethree principal paths:renunciation,bodhichitta, and the correct view of emptiness. All these accomplishments – from the attainment of Buddhahood down to the development of renunciation – depend upon relying sincerely upon our Spiritual Guide.
paragraphs.parent_section: AN EXPLANATION OF THERELATIONSHIPS OF SERIAL AND REVERSE ORDER

paragraphs.text: These two ways of looking at the interdependent relationship between the stages of the path illustrate that, if we have a sincere desire to become a Buddha, we must follow the entire path of Sutra and Secret Mantra. Spending our life on one or two meditations will not lead us to enlightenment. If we want to enjoy a cup of tea, it is not sufficient merely to have just the water, just the tea, just the milk, or just the sugar; we need to have all the ingredients together. If several different things have to be assembled for us merely to enjoy a cup of tea, how much more necessary must this be if our goal is to experience the highest enlightenment? It is unrealistic to think that we can rely upon just one or two isolated practices.
paragraphs.parent_section: AN EXPLANATION OF THERELATIONSHIPS OF SERIAL AND REVERSE ORDER

paragraphs.text: This completes the instructions on the resultant Mahamudra Union in particular and Secret Mantra Mahamudra in general. If these instructions are to be beneficial, they should not be an object of mere intellectual interest or curiosity; we must actually put them into practice under the guidance of a fully qualified Spiritual Guide.
paragraphs.parent_section: AN EXPLANATION OF THERELATIONSHIPS OF SERIAL AND REVERSE ORDER

paragraphs.text: THECONCLUDING STAGES
paragraphs.parent_section: THECONCLUDING STAGES

paragraphs.text: In theKadampa tradition’s teachings ontraining the mind, it is stated that there are certain specific activities to be done at the beginning and at the end of anyDharma practice. No matter what action we may be engaged in – whether it be study, meditation, the practice of giving, or anything else – it is important at the outset to set a correctmotivation and at the conclusion to perform correct dedication. Setting the correct motivation,bodhichitta, was explained at the beginning of this book. As for correct dedication, the function of this concluding practice is to ensure that whatever wealth of virtue has been accumulated by our Dharma activities is not wasted or exhausted, but is increased abundantly. Even if our accumulation of virtue is small, its fruit can be plentiful if we perform dedication properly.
paragraphs.parent_section: THECONCLUDING STAGES

paragraphs.text: The results of meritorious actions largely depend upon our manner of dedicating them. If our previously accumulated virtuous actions are dedicated towards enlightenment, they will definitely become the cause of our attaining perfect Buddhahood; if they are dedicated towards personal liberation from suffering, they will become the cause of our attainingnirvana; and if they are dedicated for the sake of this life’s enjoyments, their results will follow accordingly. However, this last dedication is not a pure dedication, and the one before it is not a sublime dedication. It is the first dedication that is the purest and most sublime of all. Therefore, we should dedicate whatever virtuous actions we have performed, and whatever merit we have accumulated through them, to the attainment of enlightenment for the sake of all sentient beings without exception.
paragraphs.parent_section: THECONCLUDING STAGES

paragraphs.text: Here, then, we should dedicate all the virtue of giving and listening to Mahamudra teachings, of reading Mahamudra texts, of contemplating the meaning of Mahamudra, and of meditating on the stages of Mahamudra practice, to the attainment of the Mahamudra that is the Union of No More Learning – the perfect enlightenment of Buddhahood – for the sake of benefiting all living beings. This dedication is extremely important. If it is done correctly and sincerely from the depths of our heart, the threefold practice of listening to, contemplating, and meditating on these Mahamudra teachings will be very meaningful and the source of great bliss.
paragraphs.parent_section: THECONCLUDING STAGES

paragraphs.text: Dorjechang Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche
paragraphs.parent_section: THECONCLUDING STAGES

paragraphs.text: We should pray:
To accomplish all the purposes of living beings,
By this virtue may I quickly attain
The seven pre-eminent qualities of embrace:
A Form Body endowed with the major signs and minor indications
Continuously in embrace with a wisdom knowledge consort,
A mind always abiding in a state of great bliss,
This mind of bliss always mixed with emptiness, the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena,
Endowed with great compassion that has abandoned the extreme of attachment to solitary peace,
Uninterruptedly manifesting Form Bodies that pervade the whole world,
And unceasingly performing enlightened deeds.
May everything be auspicious.

This book,Clear Light of Bliss, is the teachings of Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche. These teachings were recorded and transcribed, and then edited principally by him and some of his senior students.

sections.heading_text: THE MAHAMUDRA OF THE ORAL LINEAGE OF THE UNEQUALLED VIRTUOUS TRADITION
The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: THE MAHAMUDRA OF THE ORAL LINEAGE OF THE UNEQUALLED VIRTUOUS TRADITION
paragraphs.parent_section: THE MAHAMUDRA OF THE ORAL LINEAGE OF THE UNEQUALLED VIRTUOUS TRADITION

paragraphs.text: The Condensed Meaning of the Text
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: The explanation of the stages of how to practise the swift Vajrayana path of the Mahamudra of the oral lineage of the unequalled Virtuous Tradition has three parts:
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 1	An introduction to the general paths
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 2	The source of the lineage from which these instructions are derived
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 3	The actual explanation of the instructions possessing this lineage
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: The actual explanation of the instructions possessing this lineage has three parts:
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 1	The preliminary practices
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 2	The actual practice
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 3	The concluding stages
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: The preliminary practices has two parts:
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 1	The common preliminary practices
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 2	The uncommon preliminary practices
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: The common preliminary practices has four parts:
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 1	The guide of going for refuge and generating bodhichitta, the gateway to the Buddhadharma and the Mahayana
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 2	The guide of mandala offerings, the gateway to accumulating a collection of merit
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 3	The guide of meditation and recitation of Vajrasattva, the gateway to purifying negativities and downfalls
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 4	The guide of Guru yoga, the gateway to receiving blessings
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: The actual practice has three parts:
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 1	How to practise the Mahamudra that is the union of bliss and emptiness
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 2	How to practise the Mahamudra that is the union of the two truths
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 3	How to accomplish the Mahamudra that is the resultant Union of No More Learning, the state possessing the seven pre-eminent qualities of embrace
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: How to practise the Mahamudra that is the union of bliss and emptiness has two parts:
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 1	An explanation of the method for generating the object-possessor, spontaneous great bliss
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 2	An explanation of the method for correctly realizing the object, emptiness
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 4	An explanation of the stages of meditation on inner fire (tummo) in particular
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 2	Showing the stages by which it is gradually accomplished
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: How to accomplish the Mahamudra that is the resultant Union of No More Learning, the state possessing the seven pre-eminent qualities of embrace, has five parts:
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 1	The place where Buddhahood is attained
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 2	The basis upon which Buddhahood is attained
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 3	The way in which Buddhahood is attained
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 4	The good qualities of a Buddha
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: 5	An explanation of the relationships of serial and reverse order
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: Dedication
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: To accomplish all the purposes of living beings,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: By this virtue may I quickly attain
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: The seven pre-eminent qualities of embrace:
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: A Form Body endowed with the major signs and minor indications
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: Continuously in embrace with a wisdom knowledge consort,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: A mind always abiding in a state of great bliss,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: This mind of bliss always mixed with emptiness, the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: Endowed with great compassion that has abandoned the extreme of attachment to solitary peace,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: Uninterruptedly manifesting Form Bodies that pervade the whole world,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: And unceasingly performing enlightened deeds.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: May everything be auspicious.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

paragraphs.text: Colophon:This condensed meaning, or outline, ofClear Light of Bliss, a commentary to the practice of Mahamudra in Vajrayana Buddhism, was composed by Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Meaning of the Text

sections.heading_text: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: O Blessed One, Shakyamuni Buddha,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Precious treasury of compassion,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Bestower of supreme inner peace,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: You, who love all beings without exception,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Are the source of happiness and goodness;
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: And you guide us to the liberating path.
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Your body is a wishfulfilling jewel,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Your speech is supreme, purifying nectar,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: And your mind is refuge for all living beings.
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: With folded hands I turn to you,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Supreme unchanging friend,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: I request from the depths of my heart:
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Please give me the light of your wisdom
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: To dispel the darkness of my mind
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: And to heal my mental continuum.
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Please nourish me with your goodness,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: That I in turn may nourish all beings
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: With an unceasing banquet of delight.
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Through your compassionate intention,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Your blessings and virtuous deeds,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: And my strong wish to rely upon you,
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: May all suffering quickly cease
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: And all happiness and joy be fulfilled;
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: And may holy Dharma flourish for evermore.
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: Colophon:This prayer was composed by Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche and is recited at the beginning of teachings, meditations and prayers in Kadampa Buddhist Centres throughout the world.
paragraphs.parent_section: PRAISE TO BUDDHA SHAKYAMUNI

paragraphs.text: THE ESSENTIAL SELF-GENERATION SADHANA OF HERUKA BODY MANDALA & CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA
paragraphs.parent_section: THE ESSENTIAL SELF-GENERATION SADHANA OF HERUKA BODY MANDALA & CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: Introduction
paragraphs.parent_section: Introduction

paragraphs.text: Those who have received the empowerment of Heruka body mandala, but who are unable to practise the extensive sadhana,Essence of Vajrayana, can practise this short sadhana, which contains the very essence of Heruka body mandala practice.
paragraphs.parent_section: Introduction

paragraphs.text: It is very important to improve our understanding of and faith in this precious practice through sincerely studying its commentary as presented in the bookModern Buddhism, in the chapterThe Practice of Heruka Body Mandala. Having understood the meaning clearly and with strong faith we can enter, make progress on and complete the quick path to the enlightened state of Buddha Heruka.
paragraphs.parent_section: Introduction

paragraphs.text: Geshe Kelsang Gyatso
paragraphs.parent_section: Introduction

paragraphs.text: April 2010
paragraphs.parent_section: Introduction

paragraphs.text: The Yoga of Buddha Heruka
paragraphs.parent_section: The Yoga of Buddha Heruka

paragraphs.text: PRELIMINARIES
paragraphs.parent_section: PRELIMINARIES

paragraphs.text: Going for refuge
paragraphs.parent_section: Going for refuge

paragraphs.text: I and all sentient beings, until we achieve enlightenment,
paragraphs.parent_section: Going for refuge

paragraphs.text: Go for refuge to Buddha, Dharma and Sangha.	(3x)
paragraphs.parent_section: Going for refuge

paragraphs.text: Generating the supreme good heart, bodhichitta
paragraphs.parent_section: Generating the supreme good heart, bodhichitta

paragraphs.text: Through the virtues I collect by giving and other perfections,
paragraphs.parent_section: Generating the supreme good heart, bodhichitta

paragraphs.text: May I become a Buddha for the benefit of all.		(3x)
paragraphs.parent_section: Generating the supreme good heart, bodhichitta

paragraphs.text: Guru yoga
paragraphs.parent_section: Guru yoga

paragraphs.text: Visualization and Meditation
paragraphs.parent_section: Visualization and Meditation

paragraphs.text: In the space before me is Guru Sumati Buddha Heruka – Je Tsongkhapa inseparable from my root Guru, Buddha Shakyamuni and Heruka – surrounded by all the Buddhas of the ten directions.
paragraphs.parent_section: Visualization and Meditation

paragraphs.text: Inviting the Wisdom Beings
paragraphs.parent_section: Inviting the Wisdom Beings

paragraphs.text: From the heart of the Protector of the hundreds of Deities of the Joyful Land,
paragraphs.parent_section: Inviting the Wisdom Beings

paragraphs.text: To the peak of a cloud which is like a cluster of fresh, white curd,
paragraphs.parent_section: Inviting the Wisdom Beings

paragraphs.text: All-knowing Losang Dragpa, King of the Dharma,
paragraphs.parent_section: Inviting the Wisdom Beings

paragraphs.text: Please come to this place together with your Sons.
paragraphs.parent_section: Inviting the Wisdom Beings

paragraphs.text: At this point we imagine that wisdom being Je Tsongkhapa together with his retinue dissolves into the assembly of Guru Sumati Buddha Heruka, and they become non-dual.
paragraphs.parent_section: Inviting the Wisdom Beings

paragraphs.text: The Practice of the Seven Limbs
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: In the space before me on a lion throne, lotus and moon,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: The venerable Gurus smile with delight.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: O Supreme Field of Merit for my mind of faith,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Please remain for a hundred aeons to spread the doctrine.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Your mind of wisdom realizes the full extent of objects of knowledge,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Your eloquent speech is the ear-ornament of the fortunate,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Your beautiful body is ablaze with the glory of renown,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: I prostrate to you, whom to see, to hear and to remember is so meaningful.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Pleasing water offerings, various flowers,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Sweet-smelling incense, lights, scented water and so forth,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: A vast cloud of offerings both set out and imagined,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: I offer to you, O Supreme Field of Merit.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Whatever non-virtues of body, speech and mind
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: I have accumulated since time without beginning,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Especially transgressions of my three vows,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: With great remorse I confess each one from the depths of my heart.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: In this degenerate age you strove for much learning and accomplishment.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Abandoning the eight worldly concerns, you made your freedom and endowment meaningful.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: O Protector, from the very depths of my heart,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: I rejoice in the great wave of your deeds.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: From the billowing clouds of wisdom and compassion
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: In the space of your Truth Body, O Venerable and holy Gurus,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Please send down a rain of vast and profound Dharma
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Appropriate to the disciples of this world.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: From your actual deathless body, born from meaning clear light,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Please send countless emanations throughout the world
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: To spread the oral lineage of the Ganden doctrine,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: And may they remain for a very long time.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Through the virtues I have accumulated here,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: May the doctrine and all living beings receive every benefit.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Especially may the essence of the doctrine
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Of Venerable Losang Dragpa shine forever.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Practice of the Seven Limbs

paragraphs.text: Offering the Mandala
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: The ground sprinkled with perfume and spread with flowers,
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: The Great Mountain, four lands, sun and moon,
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: Seen as a Buddha Land and offered thus,
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: May all beings enjoy such Pure Lands.
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: I offer without any sense of loss
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: The objects that give rise to my attachment, hatred and confusion,
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: My friends, enemies and strangers, our bodies and enjoyments;
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: Please accept these and bless me to be released directly from the three poisons.
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: IDAM GURU RATNA MANDALAKAM NIRYATAYAMI
paragraphs.parent_section: Offering the Mandala

paragraphs.text: Making Special Requests
paragraphs.parent_section: Making Special Requests

paragraphs.text: O Guru Sumati Buddha Heruka, from now until I attain enlightenment,
paragraphs.parent_section: Making Special Requests

paragraphs.text: I shall seek no refuge other than you.
paragraphs.parent_section: Making Special Requests

paragraphs.text: Please pacify my obstacles and bestow upon me
paragraphs.parent_section: Making Special Requests

paragraphs.text: The two attainments of liberating and ripening.
paragraphs.parent_section: Making Special Requests

paragraphs.text: Please bless me so that I will become definitive Heruka,
paragraphs.parent_section: Making Special Requests

paragraphs.text: In which state I shall experience all phenomena as purified and gathered into emptiness, inseparable from great bliss.						(3x)
paragraphs.parent_section: Making Special Requests

paragraphs.text: Generating the Experience of Great Bliss and Emptiness
paragraphs.parent_section: Generating the Experience of Great Bliss and Emptiness

paragraphs.text: Due to my making requests in this way, all the Buddhas of the ten directions dissolve into Je Tsongkhapa who is inseparable from my root Guru, he dissolves into Buddha Shakyamuni at his heart, and Buddha Shakyamuni dissolves into Heruka at his heart. With delight, Guru Heruka, who is the nature of the union of great bliss and emptiness, enters my body through my crown, and dissolves into my mind at my heart. Because Heruka, who is the nature of the union of great bliss and emptiness, becomes inseparable from my mind, my mind transforms into the union of great bliss and emptiness of all phenomena.
paragraphs.parent_section: Generating the Experience of Great Bliss and Emptiness

paragraphs.text: We meditate on this belief single-pointedly. This meditation is called ‘training in definitive Guru yoga’. We should repeat this practice of special request and meditation again and again until we spontaneously believe that our mind has transformed into the union of great bliss and emptiness.
paragraphs.parent_section: Generating the Experience of Great Bliss and Emptiness

paragraphs.text: THE ACTUAL SELF GENERATION
paragraphs.parent_section: THE ACTUAL SELF GENERATION

paragraphs.text: In the vast space of emptiness of all phenomena, the nature of my purified mistaken appearance of all phenomena – which is the Pure Land of Keajra – I appear as Buddha Heruka with a blue-coloured body, four faces and twelve arms, the nature of my purified white indestructible drop. I am embracing Vajravarahi, the nature of my purified red indestructible drop. I am surrounded by the Heroes and Heroines of the five wheels, who are the nature of my purified subtlebody – the channels and drops. I reside in the mandala, the celestial mansion, which is the nature of my purified grossbody. Although I have this appearance it is not other than the emptiness of all phenomena.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE ACTUAL SELF GENERATION

paragraphs.text: At this point, (1) while experiencing great bliss and emptiness, (2) we meditate on the clear appearance of the mandala and Deities with divine pride, while (3) recognizing that the Deities are the nature of our purified channels and drops, which are our subtle body, and that the mandala is the nature of our purified gross body.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE ACTUAL SELF GENERATION

paragraphs.text: In this way we train sincerely in one single meditation ongeneration stage possessing these three characteristics. Holding the third characteristic – recognizing the Deities as the nature of our purified subtle body, and the mandala as the nature of our purified gross body – makes this concentration an actual body mandala meditation.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE ACTUAL SELF GENERATION

paragraphs.text: If we wish to practise completion stage meditation, we should change ourself through imagination from Heruka with four faces and twelve arms into Heruka with one face and two arms. We then engage in the meditations on the central channel, indestructible drop, indestructible wind, tummo and so forth.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE ACTUAL SELF GENERATION

paragraphs.text: Then, when we need to rest from meditation, we can practise mantra recitation.
paragraphs.parent_section: THE ACTUAL SELF GENERATION

paragraphs.text: Reciting the mantras
paragraphs.parent_section: Reciting the mantras

paragraphs.text: The Essence Mantra of Heruka
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: At my heart is wisdom being Buddha Heruka, definitive Heruka.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: O Glorious Vajra Heruka, you who enjoy
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: The divine illusory body and mind of clear light,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: Please pacify my obstacles and bestow upon me
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: The two attainments of liberating and ripening.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: Please bless me so that I will become definitive Heruka,
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: In which state I shall experience all phenomena as purified and gathered into emptiness, inseparable from great bliss.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: OM SHRI VAJRA HE HE RU RU KAM HUM HUM PHAT DAKINI DZALA SHAMBARAM SOHA
paragraphs.parent_section: The Essence Mantra of Heruka
The Essence Mantra of Heruka

paragraphs.text: The Three-OM Mantra of Vajrayogini
paragraphs.parent_section: The Three-OM Mantra of Vajrayogini

paragraphs.text: At the heart of imagined Vajrayogini (Vajravarahi) is wisdom being Buddha Vajrayogini, definitive Vajrayogini.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Three-OM Mantra of Vajrayogini

paragraphs.text: OM OM OM SARWA BUDDHA DAKINIYE VAJRA WARNANIYE VAJRA BEROTZANIYE HUM HUM HUM PHAT PHAT PHAT SOHA
paragraphs.parent_section: The Three-OM Mantra of Vajrayogini

paragraphs.text: Recite at least as many mantras as you have promised.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Three-OM Mantra of Vajrayogini

paragraphs.text: The ‘three-OM’ mantra is the union of the essence and close essence mantras of Vajravarahi. The meaning of this mantra is as follows. WithOM OM OMwe are calling Vajrayogini – the principal Deity – and her retinue of Heroines of the three wheels.SARWA BUDDHA DAKINIYEmeans that Vajrayogini is the synthesis of the minds of all Buddhas,VAJRA WARNANIYEmeans that she is the synthesis of the speech of all Buddhas, andVAJRA BEROTZANIYEmeans that she is the synthesis of the bodies of all Buddhas. WithHUM HUM HUMwe are requesting Vajrayogini and her retinues to bestow upon us the attainments of the body, speech and mind of all Buddhas. WithPHAT PHAT PHATwe are requesting them to pacify our main obstacle – the subtle mistaken appearance of our body, speech and mind; andSOHAmeans ‘please build within me the basic foundation for all these attainments’.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Three-OM Mantra of Vajrayogini

paragraphs.text: The Condensed Mantra of the Sixty-two Deities of Heruka Body Mandala
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Mantra of the Sixty-two Deities of Heruka Body Mandala

paragraphs.text: At the heart of each of the sixty-two Deities is their individual wisdom being, their own definitive Deity.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Mantra of the Sixty-two Deities of Heruka Body Mandala

paragraphs.text: OM HUM BAM RIM RIM LIM LIM, KAM KHAM GAM GHAM NGAM, TSAM TSHAM DZAM DZHAM NYAM, TrAM THrAM DrAM DHrAM NAM, TAM THAM DAM DHAM NAM, PAM PHAM BAM BHAM, YAM RAM LAM WAM, SHAM KAM SAM HAM, HUM HUM PHAT
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Mantra of the Sixty-two Deities of Heruka Body Mandala
The Condensed Mantra of the Sixty-two Deities of Heruka Body Mandala

paragraphs.text: When we recite this mantra we are making requests to wisdom being Buddha Heruka with Vajravarahi, and his retinue of Heroes and Heroines of the five wheels, to pacify our obstacle of subtle mistaken appearance and to bestow upon us the attainments of outer and inner Dakini Land. Outer Dakini Land is the Pure Land of Keajra and inner Dakini Land is meaning clear light. The moment our mind is free from subtle mistaken appearance, we open the door through which we can directly see all enlightened Deities. For as long as our mind remains polluted by subtle mistaken appearance this door is closed.
paragraphs.parent_section: The Condensed Mantra of the Sixty-two Deities of Heruka Body Mandala

paragraphs.text: Dedication
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Thus, through my virtues from correctly performing the offerings, praises, recitations and meditations
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Of the generation stage of Glorious Heruka,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: May I complete all the stages
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Of the common and uncommon paths.
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: For the sake of all living beings
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: May I become Heruka;
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: And then lead every living being
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: To Heruka’s supreme state.
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: And if I do not attain this supreme state in this life,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: At my deathtime may I be met by the venerable Father and Mother and their retinue,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: With clouds of breathtaking offerings, heavenly music,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: And many excellent, auspicious signs.
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Then, at the end of the clear light of death,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: May I be led to the Pure Land of Keajra,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: The abode of the Knowledge Holders who practise the supreme path;
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: And there may I swiftly complete this profound path.
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: May the most profound practice and instruction of Heruka,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Practised by millions of powerful Yogis, greatly increase;
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: And may it remain for a very long time without degenerating,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: As the main gateway for those seeking liberation.
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: May the Heroes, Dakinis and their retinues
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Abiding in the twenty-four supreme places of this world,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Who possess unobstructed power for accomplishing this method,
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Never waver from always assisting practitioners.
paragraphs.parent_section: Dedication

paragraphs.text: Auspicious prayers
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: May there be the auspiciousness of a great treasury of blessings
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: Arising from the excellent deeds of all the root and lineage Gurus,
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: Who have accomplished the supreme attainment of Buddha Heruka
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: By relying upon the excellent, secret path of the King of Tantras.
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: May there be the auspiciousness of the great excellent deeds of the Three Jewels –
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: The holy Buddha Jewel, the pervading nature Heruka, definitive Heruka;
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: The ultimate, great, secret Dharma Jewel, the scriptures and realizations of Heruka Tantra;
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: And the supreme Sangha Jewel, the assemblies of Heruka’s retinue Deities.
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: Through all the great good fortune there is
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: In the precious, celestial mansions as extensive as the three thousand worlds,
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: Adorned with ornaments like the rays of the sun and the moon,
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: May all worlds and their beings have happiness, goodness, glory and prosperity.
paragraphs.parent_section: Auspicious prayers

paragraphs.text: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: So that the tradition of Je Tsongkhapa,
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: The King of the Dharma, may flourish,
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: May all obstacles be pacified
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: And may all favourable conditions abound.
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: Through the two collections of myself and others
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: Gathered throughout the three times,
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: May the doctrine of Conqueror Losang Dragpa
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: Flourish for evermore.
paragraphs.parent_section: Prayers for the Virtuous Tradition

paragraphs.text: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: Tsongkhapa, crown ornament of the scholars of the Land of the Snows,
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: You are Buddha Shakyamuni and Vajradhara, the source of all attainments,
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: Avalokiteshvara, the treasury of unobservable compassion,
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: Manjushri, the supreme stainless wisdom,
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: And Vajrapani, the destroyer of the hosts of maras.
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: O Venerable Guru-Buddha, synthesis of all Three Jewels,
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: With my body, speech and mind, respectfully I make requests:
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: Please grant your blessings to ripen and liberate myself and others,
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

paragraphs.text: And bestow the common and supreme attainments.
paragraphs.parent_section: The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer
The nine-lineMigtsemaprayer

sections.heading_text: THE NINETEEN COMMITMENTS OF THE FIVE BUDDHA FAMILIES
The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:
The four commitments of the family of Buddha Akshobya:
The four commitments of the family of Buddha Ratnasambhava:
The three commitments of the family of Buddha Amitabha:
The two commitments of the family of Buddha Amoghasiddhi:
CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: Everyone who has received a Highest Yoga Tantra empowerment has a commitment to practise six-session yoga. If we are very busy, we can fulfil our six-session commitment by doing the following practice six times each day. First we recall the nineteen commitments of the five Buddha families that are listed below, and then, with a strong determination to keep these commitments purely, we recite theCondensed Six-session Yogathat follows.
THE NINETEEN COMMITMENTS OF THE FIVE BUDDHA FAMILIES
paragraphs.parent_section: THE NINETEEN COMMITMENTS OF THE FIVE BUDDHA FAMILIES

paragraphs.text: The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:
paragraphs.parent_section: The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:

paragraphs.text: 1	To go for refuge to Buddha
paragraphs.parent_section: The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:

paragraphs.text: 2	To go for refuge to Dharma
paragraphs.parent_section: The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:

paragraphs.text: 3	To go for refuge to Sangha
paragraphs.parent_section: The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:

paragraphs.text: 4	To refrain from non-virtue
paragraphs.parent_section: The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:

paragraphs.text: 5	To practise virtue
paragraphs.parent_section: The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:

paragraphs.text: 6	To benefit others
paragraphs.parent_section: The six commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana:

paragraphs.text: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Akshobya:
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Akshobya:

paragraphs.text: 1	To keep a vajra to remind us to emphasize the development of great bliss through meditation on the central channel
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Akshobya:

paragraphs.text: 2	To keep a bell to remind us to emphasize meditation on emptiness
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Akshobya:

paragraphs.text: 3	To generate ourself as the Deity while realizing all things that we normally see do not exist
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Akshobya:

paragraphs.text: 4	To rely sincerely upon our Spiritual Guide, who leads us to the practice of the pure moral discipline of the Pratimoksha, Bodhisattva and Tantric vows
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Akshobya:

paragraphs.text: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Ratnasambhava:
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Ratnasambhava:

paragraphs.text: 1	To give material help
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Ratnasambhava:

paragraphs.text: 2	To give Dharma
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Ratnasambhava:

paragraphs.text: 3	To give fearlessness
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Ratnasambhava:

paragraphs.text: 4	To give love
paragraphs.parent_section: The four commitments of the family of Buddha Ratnasambhava:

paragraphs.text: The three commitments of the family of Buddha Amitabha:
paragraphs.parent_section: The three commitments of the family of Buddha Amitabha:

paragraphs.text: 1	To rely upon the teachings of Sutra
paragraphs.parent_section: The three commitments of the family of Buddha Amitabha:

paragraphs.text: 2	To rely upon the teachings of the two lower classes of Tantra
paragraphs.parent_section: The three commitments of the family of Buddha Amitabha:

paragraphs.text: 3	To rely upon the teachings of the two higher classes of Tantra
paragraphs.parent_section: The three commitments of the family of Buddha Amitabha:

paragraphs.text: The two commitments of the family of Buddha Amoghasiddhi:
paragraphs.parent_section: The two commitments of the family of Buddha Amoghasiddhi:

paragraphs.text: 1	To make offerings to our Spiritual Guide
paragraphs.parent_section: The two commitments of the family of Buddha Amoghasiddhi:

paragraphs.text: 2	To strive to maintain purely all the vows we have taken
paragraphs.parent_section: The two commitments of the family of Buddha Amoghasiddhi:

paragraphs.text: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: I go for refuge to the Guru and Three Jewels.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: Holding vajra and bell I generate as the Deity and make offerings.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: I rely upon the Dharmas of Sutra and Tantra and refrain from all non-virtuous actions.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: Gathering all virtuous Dharmas, I help all living beings through the practice of the four givings.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: All nineteen commitments are referred to in this verse. The words,‘I go for refuge to the . . . Three Jewels’, refer to the first three commitments of the family of Buddha Vairochana – to go for refuge to Buddha, to go for refuge to Dharma and to go for refuge to Sangha. The word,‘Guru’, refers to the fourth commitment of the family of Buddha Akshobya – to rely sincerely upon our Spiritual Guide.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: The words,‘Holding vajra and bell I generate as the Deity’, refer to the first three commitments of the family of Buddha Akshobya – to keep a vajra to remind us of great bliss, to keep a bell to remind us of emptiness, and to generate ourself as the Deity. The words,‘and make offerings’, refer to the first commitment of the family of Buddha Amoghasiddhi – to make offerings to our Spiritual Guide.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: The words,‘I rely upon the Dharmas of Sutra and Tantra’, refer to the three commitments of the family of Buddha Amitabha – to rely upon the teachings of Sutra, to rely upon the teachings of the two lower classes of Tantra, and to rely upon the teachings of the two higher classes of Tantra. The words,‘and refrain from all non-virtuous actions’, refer to the fourth commitment of the family of Buddha Vairochana – to refrain from non-virtue.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: The words,‘Gathering all virtuous Dharmas’, refer to the fifth commitment of the family of Buddha Vairochana – to practise virtue. The words,‘I help all living beings’, refer to the sixth commitment of the family of Buddha Vairochana – to benefit others. The words,‘through the practice of the four givings’, refer to the four commitments of the family of Buddha Ratnasambhava – to give material help, to give Dharma, to give fearlessness and to give love.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: Finally, the entire verse refers to the second commitment of the family of Buddha Amoghasiddhi – to strive to maintain purely all the vows we have taken.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: More detail on the vows and commitments of Secret Mantra can be found in the bookTantric Grounds and Paths.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: Colophon:This sadhana or ritual prayer for spiritual attainments was complied from traditional sources by Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche, June 2009, revised April 2010 and December 2012.
paragraphs.parent_section: CONDENSED SIX-SESSION YOGA

paragraphs.text: HAM, OM,HUM,SHORT-AH

AggregateIn general, all functioning things are aggregates because they are an aggregation of their parts. In particular, a person of the desire realm or form realm has five aggregates: the aggregates of form, feeling, discrimination, compositional factors and consciousness. A being of the formless realm lacks the aggregate of form but has the other four. A person’s form aggregate is his or her body. The remaining four aggregates are aspects of his mind. SeeThe New Heart of Wisdom.
AlertnessA mental factor which is a type of wisdom that examines our activity of body, speech and mind, and knows whether or not faults are developing. SeeHow to Understand the Mind.
AryadevaA third century AD Indian Buddhist scholar and meditation master, who was a disciple of Nagarjuna.
AsangaA great Indian Buddhist Yogi and scholar of the fifth century, author ofCompendium of Abhidharma. SeeLiving Meaningfully, Dying JoyfullyandThe New Heart of Wisdom.
Aspiring bodhichittaA bodhichitta that is a mere wish to attain enlightenment for the benefit of all living beings. See alsoBodhichitta.

Atisha(AD 982-1054) A famous Indian Buddhist scholar and meditation master. He was Abbot of the great Buddhist monastery of Vikramashila at a time when Mahayana Buddhism was flourishing in India. He was later invited to Tibet where he re-introduced pure Buddhism. He is the author of the first text on the stages of the path,Lamp for the Path. His tradition later became known as the ‘Kadampa Tradition’. SeeJoyful Path of Good FortuneandModern Buddhism.
AttachmentA deluded mental factor that observes a contaminated object, regards it as a cause of happiness, and wishes for it. SeeHow to Understand the MindandJoyful Path of Good Fortune.

Basis of imputationAll phenomena are imputed upon their parts, therefore any of the individual parts, or the entire collection of the parts, of any phenomenon is its basis of imputation. A phenomenon is imputed by mind in dependence upon its basis of imputation appearing to that mind. SeeThe New Heart of WisdomandOcean of Nectar.
Beginningless timeAccording to the Buddhist world view, there is no beginning to mind, and so no beginning to time. Therefore, all living beings have taken countless previous rebirths.

BlessingThe transformation of our mind from a negative state to a positive state, from an unhappy state to a happy state, or from a state of weakness to a state of strength, through the inspiration of holy beings such as our Spiritual Guide, Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.

BodhichittaSanskrit term for ‘mind of enlightenment’. ‘Bodhi’ means ‘enlightenment’, and ‘chitta’ means ‘mind’. There are two types of bodhichitta: conventional bodhichitta and ultimate bodhichitta. Generally speaking, the term ‘bodhichitta’ refers to conventional bodhichitta, which is a primary mind motivated by great compassion that spontaneously seeks enlightenment to benefit all living beings. There are two types of conventional bodhichitta – aspiring bodhichitta and engaging bodhichitta. Ultimate bodhichitta is a wisdom motivated by conventional bodhichitta that directly realizes emptiness, the ultimate nature of phenomena. See alsoAspiring bodhichittaandEngaging bodhichitta. SeeJoyful Path of Good Fortune,Meaningful to Behold,Mirror of Dharma with AdditionsandModern Buddhism.

BodhisattvaA person who has generated spontaneous bodhichitta but who has not yet become a Buddha. From the moment a practitioner generates a non-artificial, or spontaneous, bodhichitta he or she becomes a Bodhisattva and enters the first Mahayana path, the path of accumulation. An ordinary Bodhisattva is one who has not realized emptiness directly, and a Superior Bodhisattva is one who has attained a direct realization of emptiness. SeeModern Buddhism, Joyful Path of Good FortuneandMeaningful to Behold.
Body mandalaThe transformation into a Deity of any part of the body of a self-generated or in-front-generated Deity. SeeEssence of Vajrayana,The New Guide to Dakini LandandGreat Treasury of Merit.
BuddhaA being who has completely abandoned all delusions and their imprints. Every living being has the potential to become a Buddha. SeeModern BuddhismandJoyful Path of Good Fortune.

Buddha familyThere are five main Buddha families: the families of Vairochana, Ratnasambhava, Amitabha, Amoghasiddhi and Akshobya. They are the five purified aggregates – the aggregates of form, feeling, discrimination, compositional factors and consciousness, respectively; and the five exalted wisdoms – the exalted mirror-like wisdom, the exalted wisdom of equality, the exalted wisdom of individual realization, the exalted wisdom of accomplishing activities and the exalted wisdom of the Dharmadhatu, respectively. SeeGreat Treasury of Merit.
Buddha LandThe pure environment of a Buddha.

Buddha’s bodiesA Buddha has four bodies – the Wisdom Truth Body, the Nature Body, the Enjoyment Body and the Emanation Body. The first is Buddha’s omniscient mind. The second is the emptiness, or ultimate nature, of his or her mind. The third is his subtle Form Body. The fourth, of which each Buddha manifests a countless number, are gross Form Bodies that are visible to ordinary beings. The Wisdom Truth Body and the Nature Body are both included within the Truth Body, and the Enjoyment Body and the Emanation Body are both included within the Form Body. SeeJoyful Path of Good Fortune, Tantric Grounds and PathsandOcean of Nectar.

Chandrakirti(c.7th century AD) A great Indian Buddhist scholar and meditation master who composed, among many other books, the well-knownGuide to the Middle Way, in which he clearly elucidates the view of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school according to Buddha’s teachings given in thePerfection of Wisdom Sutras. SeeOcean of Nectar.

ClairvoyanceAbilities that arise from special concentration. There are five principal types of clairvoyance: the clairvoyance of divine eye (the ability to see subtle and distant forms), the clairvoyance of divine ear (the ability to hear subtle and distant sounds), the clairvoyance of miracle powers (the ability to emanate various forms by mind), the clairvoyance of knowing previous lives, and the clairvoyance of knowing others’ minds. Some beings, such as bardo beings and some human beings and spirits, have contaminated clairvoyance that is developed due to karma, but these are not actual clairvoyance.

Clear appearanceGenerally, a clear perception of the object of meditation. More specifically, a Secret Mantra practice whereby the practitioner, having generated himself or herself as a Deity and the environment as the Deity’s mandala, tries to attain clear appearance of the whole object to his or her concentration. It is the antidote to ordinary appearance. SeeThe New Guide to Dakini LandandModern Buddhism.

Collection of meritA virtuous action motivated by bodhichitta that is a main cause of attaining the Form Body of a Buddha. Examples are: making offerings and prostrations to holy beings with bodhichitta motivation, and the practice of the perfections of giving, moral discipline and patience.
